title: Use Quarto to Build My Website
text: As a person with humanity and statistics background doing LLM today, quarto is one of a few ‚Äúpearls‚Äù I inherited from the statistics community. The primary advantage I would love to work on is the simplicity. We don‚Äôt have to spend too much time to add a new feature.

title: Use Quarto to Build My Website
text:
Some Basic Operatiosn
To build a website, we can use the online resources in create website section in quarto.
We need, however, to understand the quarto logic. The core design logic of quarto-cli following the command style
quarto <verb> [target] [options]
Common verbs mirror the workflow: - render ‚Äî run the full pipeline - preview ‚Äî render + live reload server - publish ‚Äî render + deploy to hosting - create ‚Äî scaffold new projects - check ‚Äî diagnose environment issues

title: Use Quarto to Build My Website
text:
Project Structure
There are several files that need extra attention, First, in _quarto.yml all the configurations are stored here. It is the infrastrcutre of all the important information of the project. As in 2025.12, my _quarto.yml looks like
project:
  type: website

website:
  title: "Yiyuan Li"
  navbar:
    left:
      - href: index.qmd
        text: Home # homepage link 
      - href: blog.qmd 
        text: Blog

format:
  html:
    theme:
      - cosmo
      - styles.scss 
    toc: true
Everything in here is yaml mapping. According to the definitive guide of quarto, all the yaml mapping can be described as key: value pairs. Here, the value can be int, boolean, string, a set of ordered values, and another map. The possible options, different from the syntax regulation, are be review in the reference of quartos‚Äô document.
But why? We can treat the hierarchical design of the YAML system as a systematic way to balance the consistency and flexibility of the contents within the same project. Thus, _quarto.yml provides information of the whole project, front_matter on top of each file provides page level information that can override the genernal information. Of course, for each directory (folder), we can design directory only _metadata.yml. However, there are some configuratiosn that are _quarto.yml only.






NoteQuarto project options





# Project definition
project:
  type: website | book | manuscript | default
  output-dir: _site
  resources: []
  preview:
    port: 4200
    browser: true

# Website structure
website:
  title: "Site Title"
  navbar: ...
  sidebar: ...
  search: ...
  page-footer: ...
  site-url: "https://example.com"

# Book structure  
book:
  title: "Book Title"
  chapters: ...
  appendices: ...
  
# Manuscript structure
manuscript:
  article: article.qmd
  notebooks: ...

# Build profiles
profile:
  default: production
  group: [[a, b]]

# External metadata files
metadata-files:
  - _variables.yml

# Publishing targets
publish:
  provider: gh-pages



In _metadata.yml, we mostly focus on format. The layered strcture makes any specific function has its own style.

title: Use Quarto to Build My Website
text:
Citation
We can create a variety of format using relative simple grammar (Shanny-Csik, 2022). If I want to create a citation in my blog, what I need to do is only add several lines in my yaml header in blow.
citeproc: true                                             # use cite processor 
csl: references/association-for-computational-linguistics  # use the style installed 
bibliography: "references/Website (Personal).bib"          # use the citations exported by zotero
The second advantage is the potentlity of code chuck formats

#|code-fold: true to let readers collapse the block.
#| code-summary: "Citation settings" to label the folded block.
#| code-copy: true to show a copy-to-clipboard button.
#| code-tools: true for the toolbar (copy/download).
#| code-line-numbers: true to number lines.
#| code-overflow: wrap or scroll to control horizontal overflow.
#| ode-block-bg: false to remove the background if you want the snippet to blend in.

title: Overview of My Website
text:
First, if you want to understand this website, you may view the _quarto.yml file. The file _quarto.yml is the project-level configuration file that tells Quarto how to build the site.
The directory posts/ stores all the blogs that I wrote. The file in the root directory blog.qmd is the listing page that gatheres everything under posts


quarto render ‚Äî build the project (or pass a file name) into _site/; use ‚Äìprofile prod or ‚Äìoutput-dir to customize.
quarto preview ‚Äî live-reload server for the project; auto-renders on save and opens a local URL.
quarto check ‚Äî sanity-check your install, project metadata, and rendering capabilities; add check project to focus on the current folder.
quarto inspect ‚Äî dump the final metadata that Quarto sees after all inheritance; handy to debug _metadata.yml.
quarto format ‚Äî reflow/clean markdown and code fences; good for tidying shared posts.
quarto help <command> ‚Äî built-in docs for any subcommand; e.g.¬†quarto help render lists all flags.



A code chunk ({python} ...) runs through a Quarto kernel/engine, captures outputs, and can affect the document; options inside the braces control execution and display.
A raw block ({=html} ...) is passed straight to Pandoc without evaluation; you pick the format (=html, =latex, =yaml, etc.) so it drops verbatim into the rendered output.
Raw blocks just bypass Quarto‚Äôs execution step, so #| lines aren‚Äôt interpreted there‚Äîthey come out exactly as typed. The #| option: value syntax is only recognized in executable code chunks (Python/R/etc.) and in the document front matter. If you need a raw block to contain code that controls formatting, use the appropriate Pandoc raw format tag (e.g., {=html}) and skip #| directives.

text: Yiyuan (Chris) Li (ü™Ñ they/them) is a senior undergraduate student at Reed College, where they are completing an interdisciplinary thesis on Trustworthy AI Evaluations and Vertical AI Agent Benchmarks. Their research bridges large language models, multimodal systems, and fine-grained evaluation design, with applications spanning data analysis and agentic workflows. They collaborate with Reed‚Äôs DataLab and Cerveny Lab, contributing to both AI evaluation frameworks and biological imaging pipelines.
